description: From Late Latin vulnerābilis (“injurious, wounding”), from Latin vulnerō (“I wound”).

adjectives.description: vulnerable (comparative more vulnerable, superlative most vulnerable)

definitionGroups.group: More or most likely to be exposed to the chance of being attacked or harmed, either physically or emotionally.

entries.meaning: Open to disclosing one's inner thoughts and feelings, acting in spite of one's instinct to self-preservation.
examples: It's okay to get vulnerable every now and again.

entries.meaning: (computing) More likely to be exposed to malicious programs or viruses.
examples: a vulnerable PC with no antivirus software
